content: cool so I'm Teddy CTO of RBI restaurant
Brands International and we are the company that owns Burger King Popeyes
Chicken and Tim Hortons coffee big restaurant company we operate about
25,000 restaurants around the world and we serve about a billion transactions a
year so this is a company that when we talk about our apps needs to be able to
support basically an arbitrary amount of users sessions transactions at a given
time so I want to talk a little bit about the the Popeyes app this is a
react application that we wrote and before we talk about the app I want to
talk about the popeyes chicken sandwich so this is a sandwich that we launched
on August 12th with a kind of now-infamous tweet chicken brioche
pickles new sandwich Popeyes nationwide so good forgot how to speak incomplete
sandwiches I mean sentences so this sandwich is really good I don't know if
you guys have have tried this sandwich it is truly a delicious sandwich and
when it launched kind of one of the immediate impacts that we saw people
like the sandwich and they started to go to Popeyes in very high numbers so some
of our competitor is not necessarily that thrilled about this development
trick fillet tweeted bun + chicken + pickles all the heart emoji for the
original and and in response Popeyes tweeted in typical southern fashion
y'all good so this led to what God termed the the great chicken sandwich
war of 2019 this became Twitter's conflict of the summer and as interest
in the chicken sandwich war grew other brands kind of wanted to get
involved too you can see Wendy's tweeted y'all out
here fighting about which of these fools has the second best chicken sandwich and
then Boston Market tweeted customer can I get something like Boston Market mac
and cheese but mediocre other guys my pleasure
so great chicken sandwich war escalated and
interest in the in the chicken sandwich only only grew this is actually a real
screenshot of news footage from from Grand Rapids sandwich causing traffic
jam municipal that's the part he's very upset
this is a a woman who tried 16 different Popeyes stores trying to find the the
chicken sandwich with her nephew and I think ultimately found one that was not
out of sandwiches and even some of our great cultural institutions here in
America got involved The New Yorker wrote an article the popeyes chicken
sandwich is here to save America about how our chicken sandwich was the only
thing that could unify this divided nation so we ran out we ran out of
chicken sandwiches and if you guys were following any of any of the news we very
quickly sold many many more times the number of chicken sandwiches that we
thought and which is a amazing problem to have and so the brand needed to
communicate with the customer base we're out of chicken sandwiches for now we're
working on restoring the supply chain will have more sandwiches soon I'm gonna
play a quick video that we ran on Twitter can we get sound
and the lines are crazy still till like 5:00 in the morning headlines Raptor on
all around the corner oh my god that's ridiculous when you get like five
million people six million people social media talking about this sounds is good
lights no we're sold out of chicken sandwich we
sold out of four hours
no damn chicken for Papa let's watch it again just so so like I said this this
is a react application and in the situation like what we have with Popeyes
there's a case where because of kind of a business reality that's unfolding in
real time it's incredibly important to be able to change the content on all of
our digital channels quickly right and I think this is an interesting tie into
some of the advantages that that Jam stack offers which we'll talk about in
more detail but just as an example the marketing team at Popeyes was able to
change their kind of app website from this find a Popeye's near you kind of
generic marketing content list of offers to chicken sandwich be right back
and and the team was able to do this without writing code without involving
engineering without even really involving product able to do it directly
by modifying content right not code so zooming out a little you know we own and
operate these three brands and the digital channels that we really care
about are our web apps on desktop and mobile our iOS and Android native apps
in our kiosk app and we'll talk a little more about what the kiosk is but if
you've been into one of our restaurants recently you may have encountered device
that's a touchscreen device where you can assemble your card order food
checkout and kind of a convenient smooth way for people to order food in this
store right so website iOS Android kiosk and across three brands right Burger
King Popeyes Tim Hortons so if you kind of look at the scope of what our team
has to worry about you can think of it as 12 apps and historically that's what
RBI has done maybe a totally different codebase for
Burger King website as you have for a Popeye's iOS app and six of the 12
supported digital ordering so e-commerce Dharma saps the others were maybe more
of a static application over five different agencies trying to write code
and manage this kind of patchwork of different apps and all the content data
being managed in Excel and we'll talk a little more about what we mean by
content of course we do mean things like the home screen image the headline you
see on the home page but in our case content also means the menu data what do
we sell what modifications can you make to a whopper versus ones that you're not
allowed to make and so our goal and I should mention organizationally me and
kind of other engineering folks that you'll meet at this conference join
about a year and a half ago in general and our goal when we joined try to make
one unified platform as much as we can that uses shared react components that
is much shared back-end code as we can that's able to be styled by brand and by
platform and try to make the content and data manageable and this last point is
key because in a big company but we found happens is the more painful it is
to update your content the less it happens and the less relevance that
digital channels tend to have and so if the marketers in your company kind of
fear updating the website because it involves either using some ancient CMS
or email an excel file or like calling your agency calls their sub agency calls
their sub agency who updates the website doesn't tend to happen very much so as
you saw we've got the the Popeye's web mobile app and we wanted to look at the
other apps pretty much the same way so any of you guys are Canadian you
probably know it's important food and coffee company primarily in
Canada and and same with Burger King right try to have a unified system that
we can use across the brands in order to let us think of the apps in a similar
way even if the styling and branding is totally different across the brands and
of course it is so the stock that we settled on is to
use react on on the front end and our code base is and our approach has been
very heavy on web technologies and very heavy on the browser as a rendering
engine talk a little more about that we use a lot of node lambdas on the backend
we use a surrealist framework to manage packaging up our lambda is uploading
them we we use a graph QL API to communicate between our front-end absent
and our back-end and we've set up like I'm sure many of you a headless CMS we
use a great tool called sanity i/o we'll talk a little more about about sanity
but with the goal of making the UX of updating the content as seamless as
possible and just to give you a little flavor for the app formats and kind of
delivery modes for our code we host our brand websites on that left by we we use
kind of the new generation of the ionic Cordova world for our iOS and Android
apps and and our kiosk app is a browser app using using Chrome OS so I wanted to
dive into kind of a code example I wanted to talk specifically about the
icon in the bottom nav of our mobile and mobile web apps and so if you kind of
look closely you can see we've got a maple leaf in Tim Hortons we've got a P
in Popeyes and we've got the Burger King
logo in the BK app and so with the shared code base like how do you manage
that right how do you have a different icon render dynamically into the bottom
nav so in our case what we what we do is we use the web pack build process to
conditionally load react components depending on the environment variables
that are set at build time so you can think about kind of this three by four
matrix right we've got these three brands and we've got these four
platforms we care about and what we've done is we've set up our code base so
that if you create a react component called like mobile icon Jas you can use
the file extension to define mobile icon dot thas for Tim Horton's or dot B KJ S
or dot th dot web verses th kiosk dot s right and so sure a lot of you guys have
used webpack you know that you can control a prioritized list of file
extensions that web pack will actually include into the bundle at Build time
that enables you to conditionally render different parts of of the app and so so
it sort of take them the the mobile icon as an example these are SVG is in the
codebase that that that web pack is gonna bundle or not bundle into the app
depending on what environment variables are set so you can look at these styled
components we've got a brand logo component that that's conditionally
built into the app and kind of the other key thing that we've done with our code
base is to try to try to separate cases where we need to conditionally load a
react component from cases where we actually just need to load something
from a theme value because in some ways our app is similar to maybe a Wix or a
Squarespace one of these site builders where you all you need is a configurable
theme if all your controlling our colors typefaces styles you may not need the
custom load a totally different react component you may just need to access a
theme value and load maybe themed color themes out primary type dates so the
other thing you know that's helpful for us is you can we've been able to nest
these kind of conditional loading concepts so that maybe you have a you
may have a case where the elements in the bottom now
are actually different by brand so our brands care because they're different
types of food or drink they may care differently about different different
types of functionality on digital example would be Tim Hortons is a daily
coffee they may care more about loyalty whereas maybe Popeyes may care more
about deliveries so so we're able to define even kind of the outer component
the the nav component in a custom way and then inside that still load the icon
in a custom way so you end up with kind of nesting hierarchy of custom
components so I wanted to come back to content and talk a little bit about
customizability this is something that I think when people start working on on
food apps maybe on ecommerce in general they don't totally realize just the
level of of customization that these apps allow a user to do and therefore
how many variants of a WAP are let's say can you actually order so here's a case
where let's say the user has a say that they want to order flame grilled beef
they may pick a whopper and then they may want to order that in a combo meal
format they may have a different side and drink that have different sizes
themselves and then within the sandwich they may add tomatoes remove onions they
may remove lettuce you actually end up with this fan-out effect of different
variants that you can order which is really important to manage well if you
want to run the apps so play a quick video here of something that we've set
up in order to help manage this which is our content studio and we focus both on
kind of the developer experience side of this so custom CLI that lets our
developers kind of run locally the content database and also the react
front ends of the apps our story books and so we focused heavily on kind of the
DX side of things and then also heavily on the experience for marketing because
we want them to update the data in a self-serve way we want them to do it
frequently so you can see us running yarn dev and
then so just uh sorry we'll restart this video but you can see us running yarn
dev and then the developer selecting okay I want to run locally the Popeyes
app or the Burger King app and then I want to run it in the dev environment or
the QA environment staging environment or you know I want to run it with or
without the story book to edit the react components or the content studio to edit
the data and you can see a user on the right kind of a marketing user maybe
opening up the tenders meal and adjusting the content
so one of the key things I was important for us to get right is the schema for
the content and this actually took us a while to figure out but we've figured
out kind of is that if you look at fast-food menus they do kind of conform
to a predictable schema like you usually have a bunch of sections maybe you have
a section called chicken one called beef one called drinks one called sides and
then within that maybe you have a bunch of items which are organized into
different types of formats combos they can be modified in different ways and so
one of the important things for for us did you
as we started building the apps established a data schema for kind of
what comprises a menu and one of the nice things about our CMS stack is that
it auto generates the UI for marketing to use based on the schema one of the
things that we valued about our partners at saniti so far is the ability to swap
in our own custom react components for parts of the content studio interface
we've really prioritized the UX for marketing to edit the data so it's
helpful for us if if we can write our own front-end for parts of the of the
data management interface especially as the data gets super nested and super
complicated so you started thinking about okay I'm adding Mayo to my burger
in what increments can I add the mayonnaise and whether are the
nutritional values for each of those light or very light or very heavy
mayonnaise increments so the data starts to get really detailed and it starts to
get really complicated and so it's very helpful for us to be able to swap in our
own react components that simplify parts of the editing experience for the
marketing and the food innovation teams so kind of our big-picture result here
and and this is kind of a TrueNorth for us is to have our e-commerce apps and
and our digital experiences be driven by the business folks that actually run
them and actually own the sales results so maybe in contrast to what people have
had to do historically where kind of has to be in the update loop for
a new menu item or a change to the to your web interface what we've tried to
do is empower the business groups in our company to make those updates themselves
and we've done that both because that lets them drive our business forward
better but I think also because it's an act of self-preservation like there's
not that many of us we're running these three global brands and it's really
important for us to quit the the business groups in our company with
these self-serve tools so that they don't come knock down our door every
time they need to update the home page because they're out of chicken
sandwiches or allow for a new type of customization to do a whopper so kind of
our our guiding philosophy has to try to make the tools as self-serve as we can
so just to show in practice what we mean here this is the current Popeyes website
can visit Popeyes calm and and use this application and so these are this is the
the output of the data that that our marketing teams have have put in so a
bunch of sections maybe limited-time offers chicken you know family meals
seafood sides and then as you drill deeper into the ordering experience
you're looking at the front end react application rendering the underlying
content data so if let's say the nutritional data pricing availability
changes for these items these are things that happen in the content layer not in
the code itself and so when you know for instance when we run out of chicken
sandwiches you know you may see items that appear and disappear from from our
application and and that happens very frequently and especially as our
applications expand in their scope both geographically in terms of the number of
devices screens we're running on it's really really important that this be
able to happen seamlessly so in terms of our kind of big picture
findings for running gem stack at kind of the Burger King Popeyes Tim Hortons
scale number one developer experience really important enterprise to people in
big companies are used to kind of muddling through these pretty bad
development processes where takes a long time maybe the preview changes run your
app locally see you know a lot of interconnected systems very difficult
we've tried to simplify this and and create a developer experience that it's
much more reasonable and much more similar to what people maybe who work in
smaller companies or environments are used to number two champ stock has so
far been a really good fit for kind of the organizational dynamics that that we
see in the enterprise tech and marketing groups and and what I kind of
specifically mean by that is the separation of code from from content
because when you've got different groups that may be owned different parts of the
stack it's really important to empower kind of the other folks in your org to
directly own whether it's the pages or the e-commerce you know product items
that that they're responsible for for running and and then third your stack
can kind of make or break your ability to execute in real time so when we when
we because these brands and as you kind of saw from the great sandwich war of
2019 because these brands are operating you know no longer on the scale of maybe
I publish a new item or I adjust my menu or I just availability every month every
six months it's you know the the kind of e-commerce world that we increasingly
live in it's important to be able to make updates in real time and so the way
you set up your stack can kind of make or break that ability and I think it's
important to set up your stack anticipating that okay it may not happen
today but a couple months from now someone from marketing or PR someone
from communications they're gonna want to make a change they're gonna want to
do it in like five seconds so I think it's really important to anticipate kind
of the organizational dynamics and the speed at which you're going to
need to make changes and set up your stack accordingly so we're excited to
meet you guys were here a bunch of us from the engineering product groups we'd
love to answer any questions you may have about our stack or our food and
we're growing the team primarily so far in Miami and Toronto but also in other
places and we'd love to meet you guys so please find us during the break thanks
so much [Applause]
[Applause]
you
